awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a next-generation landmine detection biosensor that can be distributed in a wide range of fields, in various environmental conditions. The project's primary goal is to provide a safe and efficient method to detect landmines, which are often buried and camouflaged, causing a significant threat to both military forces and civilians. The current detection methods are outdated and risky, requiring physical on-site presence, and they are also costly. Therefore, the proposed project aims to provide a more efficient and cost-effective solution by utilizing genetic engineering, microbiology, and biochemical approaches. The innovative biosensor system will employ two biosensors that are engineered to use TNT/DNT and toluene as the sole nitrogen-source and carbon source, respectively, to detect landmines and generate fluorescent signals that can be amplified several folds for easy detection.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a highly sensitive landmine detection biosensor. The proposed biosensor will employ bioreporter, genetic engineering, microbiology, and biochemical approaches. The key features of this technology include (1) signal amplification, (2) extreme environment adaptation, and (3) TNT/DNT-response. The project's potential benefits extend beyond landmine detection and clearance, as it can enhance our understanding of bio- and nano-technology in explosive detection. It can also contribute to socioeconomic development by providing a cost-effective solution for detecting landmines globally, where there are currently an estimated 100 million landmines in the ground, and mine action costs exceed $500 million annually. Therefore, this innovative landmine biosensor system can potentially reduce the morbidity and mortality caused by the buried landmines and promote socioeconomic development in affected regions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project is to generate a next-generation biosensor system which will have dramatically increased sensitivity to allow for the accurate detection of landmines. This biosensor system (1) can be delivered on a wide scale to current minefields; (2) has a high degree of sensitivity; (3) can produce amplified signals for detection easily and rapidly; (4) has a biological sensor that itself is safe by making each biological unit self-limiting; (5) can reduce the cost to produce biosensors; and (6) does not require physical presence. 

For years, the detection of landmine relies on the traditional metal detector and this technique requires the presence of the deminer in the field.  However, the physical presence of the deminer always leads to very high casualties.  For example, at least 4,710 people were killed or injured by landmines or explosive remnants in 2022.  Furthermore, false positive is also a major issue for this technique.  Since the main explosive component of landmine is trinitrotoluene (TNT), targeted genetic engineering approach and random mutagenesis approach have been used for the construction of either bacterial or non-bacterial biosensor for TNT detection.  However, the microorganisms that hosted these bioreporters are not robust enough for an extensive application in the field.  The signal released from the microorganism is very weak and this increases the difficulty to detect the signal.  Furthermore, they are opportunistic pathogens and might potentially cause environmental contamination.

To circumvent the concerns, we have chosen the environmentally safe, natural soil bacteria Pseudomonas putida, as our biosensor host.  Our design can produce a landmine detection biosensor system with a highly sensitive bioreporter. This biosensor system can produce amplified signals and can survive under extreme environment.  The innovation of this system lies in its two-biosensor detection mechanism.   More specifically, the mechanism begins when one biosensor detects the presence of TNT/DNT, and it will emit fluorescence.  Since this biosensor is engineered to use TNT/DNT as its sole nitrogen-source, this first biosensor will degrade TNT/DNT to toluene.  Subsequently, the second biosensor, which is engineered to use toluene as carbon source, detects the toluene and emits fluorescence.  As such, two host biosensors will be created for this system, and each host biosensor carries a unique bioreporter, respectively. The first bioreporter, which will be delivered into the first host biosensor, will be engineered to detect the presence of TNT/DNT, and the second bioreporter, which will be delivered into the second host biosensor, will be a plasmid construct that can detect the presence of toluene.  Both bioreporters carry green fluorescent reporter protein so that the biosensor system can emit fluorescence in the presence of TNT/DNT, and the signal has already been doubled compared to all previous designs.  Furthermore, we will use a unique encapsulation technique, which can dramatically amplify the signals and bring the total fluorescence magnification up several hundred-fold.  Our biosensor system is novel and sensitive for easy remote landmine detection through drone with UV camera for accurate mine distribution map. This technology has received USPTO patent with No. US11421236 B21.

This project can enhance our understanding on the application of bio- and nano-technology in explosive detection.  It is estimated that globally there are 100 million landmines in the ground and the annual worldwide expense of mine actions is at least $500 million dollars. Therefore, landmine detection presents a huge global market potential, and our landmine biosensors can effectively help to detect and remove the landmines. In terms of societal impact, among all threats from armed conflicts, landmines present huge threat to both military forces and civilians.  This is because collateral damage and death of noncombatants does not dissipate with time. Although community landmine awareness, mental health counselling and support are critical to the social economic impact of landmine, the most important factor is landmine detection and clearance.  Therefore, our next generation highly sensitive landmine detection biosensor can reduce the morbidity and mortality caused by the buried landmines, and thus promote socioeconomic development in the affected region.
